author: Bloomberg.com
title: SeaWorld Falls as Breeding Ban Forces Review of New Whale Homes
text:
SeaWorld Entertainment Inc., the embattled theme-park operator, fell as much as 6.3 percent on Friday after saying it will review plans to build a new killer whale habitat in San Diego, in light of new restrictions enacted by California regulators.
SeaWorld declined 3.1 percent to $18.53 at 11:37 a.m. in New York, after dropping as low as $17.92, for the biggest intraday drop since Aug. 24. Through Thursday, the shares had advanced 6.8 percent in 2015.
The California Coastal Commission, which regulates construction activity along the state’s shoreline, approved the company’s plan to build an expanded habitat for killer whales at its San Diego theme park, SeaWorld said Friday in a statement. The commission attached conditions that included a ban on breeding the animals within the company’s facilities.
“We are disappointed with the conditions they have placed on their approval,” Chief Executive Officer Joel Manby said in the statement. “Depriving these social animals of the natural and fundamental right to reproduce is inhumane and we do not support this condition.”
SeaWorld Intraday Chart
The Orlando, Florida-based company has faced ongoing pressure from animal activists since the release of the 2013 documentary “Blackfish,” which argued that killer whales shouldn’t be kept in captivity. In August 2014, the company unveiled a plan to spend several hundred million dollars to expand the tanks at parks in California, Texas and Florida, in part to placate activists who say the whales don’t have enough room to swim, and turn angry because of the close quarters.
The San Diego enclosure was to open in 2018, the company said at the time. SeaWorld hasn’t broken ground on any of the new habitats, according to Fred Jacobs, a spokesman.
